every intention of making that

over there's a super simple way of

and now what you want to do is you want
to bring this up to a boil and you want
to reduce all all of the crystallized
sugar so this will take a few minutes as
the water comes up in temperature it
will start dissolving those big crystals
and then eventually they'll just turn
into sugar syrup and then you can start
the process of caramelizing the sugar
over again always when you're making
caramel you want to make sure to have
one of two things a brush with a little
bit of water so you could brush down the
sides of the pan if any crystals form or
the same thing works with a lid because
the the lid does is the steam rises to
the top collects on the lid and then it
washes the crystals that form down along
the side of the pan almost like it's
raining so you can keep this lid on
until your sugar syrup starts to
caramelize so give it a check every once
in a while to make sure it's cooking and
caramelizing so it's been a few minutes
let's see how our sugar syrup is doing
it looks great it's nice and viscous you

start rotating your pot swirling it

with this you could make

so really all it takes is that little
bit of extra water to dissolve the
crystallized sugar you don't need to add
any more sugar to your syrup because
what's happening in this process and in
the process of making caramel in general
is that all of the water is evaporating
and you're really only left with sugar
in the end now as always with caramel
whenever you're making it in a darker
